text: learning the rhythm of another language
is not necessarily an easy thing to do
that's why I've created this follow up
lesson on rhythm I thought it would be
helpful for you to have additional
practice with stress and phrases and at
the sentence level we're going to begin
by reviewing those rhythmic patterns I
presented in lesson 8 and then I'm going
to share a couple new ones with you here
are the lesson objectives to strengthen
your understanding of rhythm at the
sentence level to strengthen your
ability to read aloud with natural
rhythm to help you begin to apply
rhythmic pattern as an oral reading to
free speech so if you're ready now let's
get started
remember pattern 1 when we speak in
phrases and at the sentence level we
usually stress content words and not
function words content words include
nouns verbs adverbs adjectives and
numbers function words include articles
short prepositions helping verbs and
most pronouns
example can we talk about hairstyles
it'll be fun
I promise exercise one read the
following three statements aloud try to
identify and then stress all the content
words finally listen to the correct
reading and repeat if you need more time
to read these statements use the pause
button
now listen and repeat 1 I've had long
straight hair for most of my life - a
simple hairstyle makes life easier
3 I admit that I've had a few bad
haircuts in the past
remember pattern 2 when words are
grouped into meaningful phrases or
thought groups there is usually one word
that received the most stress that word
is generally the final content word
example how would you describe your
present hairstyle is it conservative do
you think that your hairstyle reflects
your personality
exercise to read the following text
aloud try to identify the main groupings
of words were thought groups and then
stress the final content word in each
group finally listen to my reading with
the recommended rhythm and repeat again
if you need more time use the pause
button
now listen and repeat this is
embarrassing I admit the hairstyle was
bad around 12 or 13 I cut my hair short
I don't know why let me make a quick
note here about numbers numbers like 13
14 15 and so on have shifting stress
meaning it can be on the first or second
syllable now when we count the stress is
on the first syllable
for example 10 11 12 13 and my text here
13 is part of a phrase and it's the last
word in a phrase it's the last word
before pause in this case we shift the
stress to the second syllable
if 13 is not the last word in a phrase
then we tend to shift the stress back to
the first syllable so if I said I was 13
years old
stress is on the first syllable 13 years
old understand let's go on read part be
aloud as you think it should be read
now listen and repeat at this time I
think it was Princess Diana who
influenced fashion perhaps this was a
sorry attempt to look like a princess
remember pattern three instead of
stressing each Content word in a cluster
the speaker may choose to alternate the
stress so that there is a more natural
flow and rhythm example 1 do you have
many photos of yourself as a child in
this example I did not stress the word
many many as a Content word but because
we had too many stress syllables
together there's a better flow if many
is not stressed so the resulting rhythm
is 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 have photos yourself
child do you have many photos of
yourself as a child number two I'll bet
there is some you don't like to show to
people here I did not stress the verb
like although like is a Content word the
flow is a little more natural without
stressing all those content words in the
second half of the sentence now
sometimes you can read a sentence with
more than one pattern and still some
natural for example I could choose to
stress in the second half of the
sentence only like and people the result
would be like this I'll bet there are
some you don't like to show to people
that is at a very fast tempo because now
I'm only stressing to content words in
that final thought group both ways are
natural in both ways are acceptable
exercise three read each statement aloud
stress only those content words that
allow you to keep a regular rhythm
finally listen to my reading with the
recommended rhythm and repeat read
statement one aloud now listen and
repeat as a little girl I often wore
pigtails here we did not stress wore
read statement - aloud
now listen and repeat around age eight
or nine my hair looked rather wild an
alternative reading would stress only
hair and wild in the second half of the
sentence the sentence would then have to
be read at a faster tempo listen to the
result around age eight or nine my hair
looked rather wild both ways are
acceptable both ways are natural read
statement three aloud
now listen and repeat when Jennifer was
15 curly hair was in here we did not
stress hair here 15 is at the end of a
phrase so the second syllable is
stressed also here in is not a
preposition it's not a function word
it's an adverb it's part of a phrasal
verb be in so we're going to stress it
because n is at the end of the sentence
it's at the end of a thought group
remember pattern for native speakers
break normal rhythmic patterns when it's
necessary to emphasize certain words
doing so can contrast to ideas or
clarify a misunderstanding example some
people take a short amount of time to
style their hair others take a long time
here the stressed words create a
contrast
exercise for read each statement aloud
try to stress those content words that
either contrast two ideas or clarify a
misunderstanding finally listen to my
reading with the recommended rhythm one
read the statement aloud
now listen and repeat as a young girl I
experimented with hair styles now that
I'm older I'm more conservative to read
the statement aloud
now listen and repeat I'll share a few
more photos but nothing that's too
embarrassing we're not done yet
please go on to the next part of this
lesson
